title: Private Companies Shake Up Mexico City’s Earthquake-Alert System
text:
MEXICO CITY—Two years after a devastating earthquake struck Mexico City, killing more than 200 people and damaging thousands of buildings, the city’s government is feuding with private technology startups over who warns residents about approaching temblors.

Last month, the city issued a new decree that the only entity allowed to send early earthquake warnings was a Mexican nonprofit known as the Center for Seismic Instrumentation and Registry, or Cires.

The system gives Mexicans about a minute of advance warning for most strong earthquakes originating off the west coast and is widely considered reliable and fast. But two tech startups, Grillo and SkyAlert, are trying to improve upon it—to the city government’s irritation.

Cires’ 96 sensors, most placed on the Pacific Coast, detect seismic waves from an earthquake and transmit them via radio frequencies. If the quake is determined to be strong enough to cause damage, the alerts are broadcast on TV and radio and over a public address system that blares out prerecorded messages from roughly 12,000 loudspeakers mounted on telephone poles, and some 20,000 radio speakers in public schools.

Grillo and SkyAlert are pushing a more digital approach, transmitting warnings more quickly via wireless internet networks, processing seismic data using cloud-computing and offering wider coverage through media including smartphone applications, Twitter , and in-home alarms.

Both companies have built their own networks of sensors using technology originally developed for cellphones, and have the backing of venture capital funds and major research universities in the U.S. SkyAlert aims to earn profits selling premium smartphone apps and its alarm devices, while Grillo’s business model relies on selling data to insurers on neighborhoods and buildings that are most vulnerable to earthquake damage.

The city says having too many alert services is confusing for residents and can undermine confidence in the whole idea of early alerts.

“If we continue to over-alert people, it will have two effects: we’ll lose people’s trust, and we’ll cause mass panic in places like subway cars or in large office buildings,” says Guillermo Ayala, who heads natural disaster early-warning efforts for Mexico City.

Mr. Ayala points to two alerts emitted by SkyAlert’s application in August and February, which both overstated the magnitude of earthquakes and that he says caused tens of thousands of workers to leave work. He added that too many private companies seek to import cheap sensors from Asia without adapting them to Mexico.

“The point is not to prohibit the emission of seismic alerts,” Mr. Ayala said. “The more support we have, the safer we will be, but only as long as all the alerts comply with the technical regulations.”

Relatives of children who lost their lives during the 2017 earthquake in Mexico City prayed on the anniversary last year. The city is fighting with private companies over who is allowed to issue earthquake warnings. Photo: sáshenka gutierrez/epa-efe/rex/EPA/Shutterstock

SkyAlert, founded by a telecommunications engineer named Alejandro Cantu, launched its own system in 2013, rebroadcasting alerts from Cires using the same technology that pagers use, and later launching a Twitter account and an app. (Cires doesn’t offer an app. It has a Twitter account, but it tweets more than just seismic alerts.)

In 2016, SkyAlert stopped using Cires’ signal and began to rely on sensors it imported from Japan. The company also offers a device for larger buildings like factories or apartment blocks called the Epicenter, which costs about $2,000 a year.

In response to the city’s criticism of SkyAlert, Mr. Cantu said that no early warning system is perfect, and that more competition forces warning systems to improve. Mexico City’s new regulation “sends a terrible message” to people trying to make residents safer using technology, he said.

“If we put in laws that limit innovation, we are doomed to forever have the same system that was installed years ago,” Mr. Cantu said.

Mexico’s public early warning system is the world’s oldest, although Japan and Taiwan operate similar systems. It began in 1991, shortly after a 1985 earthquake devastated Mexico City, and began issuing public warnings via radio and TV in the mid-1990s.

In 2012, Mexico installed early-alert devices in public schools and launched the city’s public-address speaker system. It expects to expand the number of loudspeakers to 18,000 by the end of next summer. Cires also commercializes its alerts via a device that costs about $2,000 and provides alarms for large buildings.

Private sector firms could offer a similar system for far cheaper, according to Anglo-Colombian architect Andrés Meira, who founded Grillo in 2014. His startup operates a network of roughly 50 sensors that it designs and has manufactured in China and broadcasts alerts on Twitter and through an app. Grillo plans to start selling a small, in-home early-alert device that costs around $50.

Mr. Meira says he is optimistic that Grillo will be able to comply with the new Mexico City regulation, which he described as vaguely worded.

A seven-story office building was destroyed in the 2017 Mexico City earthquake. Forty-nine people died in the collapse. Photo: Miguel Tovar/Associated Press

“The poorest people in Mexico live in the worst-designed houses, so you have to reach those people,” Mr. Meira says. “If you just sell early alert devices to a few large skyscrapers, you’re not going to save many lives.”

With funding from the Rockefeller Foundation and in partnership with seismologists at Harvard University, Grillo also plans to install 250 more sensors in Mexico City over the next year to widen its coverage.

The rise of private-sector earthquake apps is a side effect of cellphone technology. Most smartphones contain a device called an accelerometer, which detects movement and allows phones to detect when they are being turned sideways, so that screen views can shift.

The profusion of smartphones has driven down the price of this technology, making it possible to buy a seismic sensor with an accelerometer in it for about $100. This is great news for poor countries that are vulnerable to tremors, such as Nepal, where a 2015 quake killed more than 2,000 people, says Diego Melgar, a seismologist at the University of Oregon.

Fighting over who is allowed to issue warnings is counterproductive, says Mr. Melgar, who is working on a public-private partnership in the U.S. to develop ShakeAlert, a public early warning system in California, because the more companies or agencies sharing data, the better we understand earthquakes and are able to prevent loss of life and property.

“More sensors are most definitely a good thing, because they mean more accurate coverage,” he said. “There’s going to need to be some sort of rapprochement eventually, where the government and the private sector come together and coordinate how to talk to the public.”

Write to Robbie Whelan at robbie.whelan@wsj.com
description: Two years after a devastating earthquake struck Mexico City, killing more than 200 people and damaging thousands of buildings, the city’s government is feuding with private technology startups over who is allowed to warn city residents about future quakes.
